div.div:
Please check back frequently for updates on McCurdy Charter's CO-VID 19 response.
How can you help stop the spread?
- Wash your hands often using soap and water. Wash your hands for at least 20 seconds.
- Avoid touching your face.
- Avoid social interactions. Stay home to help stop the spread.
- Stay informed and make sure your information comes from credible sources like cdc.gov

p.span: April 17, 2020

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: We have several updates and community announcements.

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: The 2020/21 school year calendar has been approved by the Governance Board. Please note that the calendar includes 6 planned early release days for students. Lunch will not be served on early release days and staff will be participating in professional development in the afternoon. The daily start and end times for students have also been changed, as indicated on the calendar.
We know that there is a lot of uncertainty because of COVID-19 and the calendar may be changed in response. We will keep you informed as we keep moving forward.
We are requesting feedback on our 2020/21 school budget. Please complete this short survey about your priorities for the school:
Thank you to everyone who already completed a Title IV survey. This is not the same survey, although it has similar questions.
There will be an opportunity to provide budget or Indian Education feedback through public comment at the next Governance Board meeting on May 21, 2020.

STUDENTS: please continue to participate actively in your classes! To earn a passing grade for quarter four, students must be participating as much as possible online, offline, or both. We know there are many factors at play - please reach out if you need support keeping engaged. We will work with you to create a plan!
The Native American Parent Committee will be meeting virtually soon. If you are interested in joining, please contact

span.style: font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#1155CC

p.span: TAP (Teachers and parents group) is looking for pictures for the elementary yearbook. Please email

span.style: font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#1155CC

p.span: if you would like to make a submission.

Breakfast and lunch grab and go will be available for free throughout the rest of the school year. You can pick up meals in our drop off lanes on the south side of campus Monday - Thursday from 8:30 - 1:00. Thursday meals will also include meals for Friday. Can’t make it to campus? You can pick up meals at any public school site, free of charge. Students are no longer required to be in the car to pick up meals.
A big thank you to all the students and their families for your efforts to attend classes or participate regularly! We love seeing your faces.

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: Thank you to our IT team for keeping us connected!

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: Thank you to the teachers and support staff for reaching out to support our students and families. We are McCurdy Strong and McCurdy Proud.

span.style: font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#1155CC

p.span: Abril 17, 2020
Tenemos actualizaciones y anuncios de la comunidad.

El calendario del ciclo escolar 2020/21 ya fue aprobado por la junta de gobierno. Favor noten que el calendario incluye seis días donde los estudiantes saldrán temprano. En estos días no se proveerá lonche y los empleados estarán participando en desarrollos profesionales durante la tarde. La entrada y salida de los estudiantes también fue cambiada tal cual se indica en el calendario.
Se que aun existe mucha incertidumbre sobre el COVID-19 y el calendario pueda cambiar. Estaremos informando.
Estamos pidiendo retroalimentación para el presupuesto del ciclo escolar 2020/21. Favor de llenar la siguiente encuesta acerca de las prioridades en nuestra escuela.

span.style: font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black

p.span: Gracias a todas las personas que ya completaron la encuestas sobre Title IV. Estas dos son encuestas diferentes a pesar de que tienen preguntas similares. Tendremos oportunidad de presentar en la siguiente junta de gobierno nuestro presupuesto o la retroalimentación de la educación india a la audiencia el día 21 de Abril 2020.

¡Estudiantes, por favor continúen para participar activamente en sus clases! Para obtener la calificación aprobatoria para este trimestre. Ya sea por medio del internet o paquetes. Sabemos que muchos factores que a veces no permiten esto, Favor de dejar saber a sus maestros como podemos ayudar. ¡Haremos todo lo posible por ayudarlos!

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: El comité de padres Nativos Americanos estarán juntándose pronto. Si estas interesado en atender, por favor contáctanos en

span.style: font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: TAP (el grupo de maestros y padres) esta en busca de fotos para el Anuar de la primaria. Favor de mandar las a

span.style: font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: si quieres poner algunas.

El almuerzo y lonche agarra y ve sigue gratis por el resto del ciclo escolar. Puedes recoger las comidas en las líneas donde se dejan a los niños al sur de nuestras instalaciones de lunes a jueves. De 8:30-1:00. El jueves incluye la comida para el viernes. ¿Si no puedes llegar a las instalaciones? Puedes recoger las comidas en cualquier escuela pública, gratis o con algún cargo. Los estudiantes no requieren y estar en el carro para recogerlas.

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

u.span: Gritos de orgullo para los Bobcats

p.span: Gracias a lo grande a los estudiantes y papas por el esfuerzo de atendar a sus clases y participar regularmente. Nos encanta ver su carita.

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

span.style: font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"

p.span: Gracias a los maestros y empleados de soporte por buscar maneras de ayudar a nuestros estudiantes y familias. Somos McCurdy fuertes McCurdy orgullo.

cmartinez@mcsk12nm.org

div.p: We have several announcements for our community:
As a reminder, we will not have classes on Friday, April 10 or Monday, April 13. We hope that you will enjoy a peaceful weekend with your families.

Grab-and-go meals will continue to be available for pickup on both days. Due to a change in rules from the USDA, students do NOT need to be in the car to pick up meals. Meals continue to be supplied free of charge to any child at any school site, whether the child attends that school or not. Please feel free to visit Pojoaque or Espanola District sites (or other school sites) if it is easier for your family, or invite others to visit MCS for meal pickup.

hr.p: Beginning on April 16, we will provide double service on Thursdays for grab-and-go meals. Families will be able to pick up meals for Thursday AND Friday and meals will not be provided on Friday. This will allow our food providers to minimize their personal risk and get a much needed break. This will not begin until April 16.
Project Carino will continue to offer support services to MCS students. Please see the attached letter from Project Carino for more information.

p.strong: In addition to the regulary scheduled classes and enrichment offerings we are providing, APS is providing the following learning opportunity to students in New Mexico:

hr.p: In response to the coronavirus crisis that has resulted in the closures of all New Mexico public schools, New Mexico PBS and Albuquerque Public Schools announce an ambitious and vital new broadcast initiative to support at-home learning for K-5 students and their families, by broadcasting a new weekday morning schedule of televised APS classes.
Beginning Monday, April 6, APS @HOME will begin broadcasting from 8 a.m.-noon weekdays on Channel 5.1. Educational programs also will be posted to the APS YouTube Channel. External link
APS @HOME will also be simulcast on the state’s other PBS stations, KENW in Portales and KRWG in Las Cruces, benefiting children statewide.
APS @HOME will give students in grades K-5 the chance to resume lessons in key topics as determined by the district.

ul.li: 8 a.m.: Grades K-1 Fundamentals/English Language Arts Writing

hr.p: The daily lesson plans will be broadcast each day, and will then be available later for individual “on-demand lessons.” These supplemental learning videos feature APS educators in short segments, supporting a variety of subjects and grade levels, including English language arts, math, visual and performing arts, physical education, and more.
These segments will also include a Sign interpreter in the lower left portion of the screen, making them accessible to the hearing impaired. Bilingual lessons are also available.

Distance learning has proven to be a challenge in New Mexico due to equity and accessibility issues. Not all households have access to digital devices, or the connectivity means to benefit from online learning.

“Our students are living through unprecedented times. There’s so much that’s out of our control right now. That’s why we have to do everything possible to meet the educational needs we can manage,” said APS Superintendent Raquel Reedy. “It may be a while before we can ensure every school-aged child has a laptop and Wi-Fi access, but we know most students have TVs in their homes. NMPBS is a familiar and trusted friend to most of us. We are grateful to extend continuous learning opportunities to students with assistance from America’s leading educational broadcast group.”

“Public television was born of a vision that television would be the world’s most powerful educational tool,” said Franz Joachim, General Manager and CEO, New Mexico PBS (NMPBS). “Today that vision still lives, as we return to our roots in educational television. Education has always been the root of who we are. And as part of both Albuquerque Public Schools and the University of New Mexico, education is essential to what we will always be. How could we not do this for New Mexico’s kids?”

ul.li: New Mexico PBS (NMPBS)/KNME Channel 5.1 (Santa Fe, Albuquerque, Northern, and Central New Mexico)

hr.p: Special thanks, to the APS educators who have gone above and beyond to make this APS @HOME service a reality. It’s time for class – at least on TV. For more information about the programming schedule, please visit the APS or NMPBS External link websites.
For more information and to watch a recorded interview about the lessons visit: https://www.facebook.com/nminfocus/videos/254656095560819/

span.span: Are you a Native high school or college student, parent, family member, counselor, tribal liaison or educator seeking advice regarding the college process in the time of COVID-19? We know there are many questions on how to best advise students and families in these uncertain times.

br.span: is a 501c3 non-profit (located in Bernalillo, NM) dedicated to increasing the number of Native American, Alaska Native and Native Hawaiian students succeeding in college and graduate programs. We have launched a
, which includes links to important information on financial aid, college admission policies, standardized testing, and more. The page also includes an
which is open to the public - we welcome questions you may have regarding the college-going process and will do our best to respond in a timely manner.
All Native students, families, and educators are also invited to join us for our upcoming

strong.em: Planning for College During COVID-19 Webinar

br.span: . We hope to alleviate anxieties and answer questions regarding the college-going process. Please register in advance

hr.p: March 27, 2020
Dear Bobcat Families,

It has only been two weeks since our Governor announced the three-week closure of all schools – it feels like two months (or years!). Today, as you may already know, the Public Education Department announced that school campuses would be closed for the rest of this school year. Fortunately, our staff has been planning for possible extended closure since that day two weeks ago and we spent much of today working together to plan for continuous learning opportunities for our McCurdy Bobcats.

The school year is not over, it will just end very, very differently than we could have predicted back in August when we began. Right now, as I type this letter, we have dedicated staff at home working on plans for learning which will include online live instructional time, tutoring, and enrichment. This plan is very much under development and we expect some successes, some failures, and everything in between as we learn together. I am going to try to break down the important information and plan (so far) into categories, which will likely prove to be a lengthy read. Are you ready? Let’s go!

span.span: Our focus for learning: Love learning and learn together.

hr.p: We will be sharing a schedule of learning for all grades, K-12. We have adopted a regular schedule so that our kids have the most stable and predictable learning environment possible. We are including a detailed schedule that shows when all classes and supports are happening. This presents a challenge because we are a K-12 school. Please feel free to ask questions or give us feedback on the schedule format. The schedule also includes times when we are offering tutoring, wellness classes, elementary art and PE, and other activities that all students are invited to attend. Special education enrichment classes are also included on the schedule.

In addition to the overall schedule, you and/or your student should get emails directly from teachers inviting you to online meetings. Secondary teachers are using Google classroom to help coordinate assignments and meetings, and many elementary teachers are also using Google classroom.
We will begin meeting with students on Monday, March 30. Elementary will meet at 9:00 with their teachers, secondary will meet at 10:00 with their FIRST PERIOD teachers.

The first week of online contact will be spent on reconnecting, assessing student needs, and helping them figure out the technology. We are going to try our best to stick to the schedule we have developed, however, we also want to be flexible and make changes if it means helping our students more effectively. We will do everything we can to keep you informed. We will share a finalized schedule no later than Sunday by 5:00 p.m. We expect confusion and difficulty, we will do our best to adapt and support you through it.

Teachers and support staff will be online daily from 8:00 – 3:30. During office hours/student support, students can work with teachers or other staff on essential skill building or even just ask questions. We encourage you to use this time with teachers and other staff. Emailing during this time is also welcome and encouraged. Students who miss their scheduled online session can also use this team to meet with their teacher to cover the material or ask questions.

School leadership, including special education and the school counselor, are also available via email during this time. We will be attending and supporting during instructional time as much as we can. Please let us know how we can help and support you and your student(s).

Grades for quarter 4 will be Pass/Fail grades. It is important that you and your student(s) understand that in order to pass their course and get credit, they need to complete the work assigned in the 4th quarter. Students who cannot attend online sessions due to a lack of technology or internet must complete the hard copy packet/project assigned by their teacher to earn their Pass grade. If you choose not to have your child participate during quarter 4, they will receive a Fail and they may fail the second semester of the course.

We understand that technology limitations are a significant barrier for many students. Teachers also understand this and are creating work that students can reasonably complete at home. The time students spend online with teachers will be primarily focused on building essential skills, providing support, and connecting with each other. Pass/Fail grades for quarter 4 will NOT affect GPA, but they WILL be used to help determine if a student passes the spring semester.

Students who complete the 4th quarter assignments/projects with a Pass and had a passing grade in 3rd quarter will receive their semester credit. Students who failed quarter 3 need to work closely with their teacher to make sure and pass quarter 4. We will look closely at their work during quarter 3 and 4 combined to determine if they have shown they should pass for the semester.

We know that many students need chromebooks. We are working to sanitize and prepare the chromebooks for check out. Information about when and where to pick up the chromebooks will be sent out next week. Additionally, teachers are preparing packets for students who do not have tech at home. ONLY students without internet will be given printed materials (other than consumables). We expect that students with internet will use digital materials and/or print at home. We also expect students to turn work in digitally as much as possible. We are going to install a drop box in the drop off lanes for students who need to return hard copies of work.

Unfortunately, we cannot provide hotspots or internet at this time. There are several companies, including Windstream, that are offering free wifi. For more information please visit our website > CO-VID 19 > other resources. Resources are also posted on newmexico.gov.
All spring standardized testing has been cancelled. We encourage you to use Istation resources for your K-3 students, but they will not take the test again this spring.
Prom has been postponed indefinitely. We will be reaching out to the Junior class sponsor and representatives to talk about options. We are in favor of a summer prom if students are interested.
Unfortunately, the spring athletics season is also cancelled. Rest assured; we plan to return in the fall!

Seniors – we are with you. We know that for many of you this came as a big blow. However, we want you to know that we have every intention to support you through this and have graduation in some form. We have a few options in mind that we will discuss with you and your parents very soon. In the meantime – Seniors, it is CRITICAL that you continue to work with your classes and teachers. DO NOT QUIT WORKING. We have several students who need to pass an assessment for graduation – this is STILL REQUIRED. Keep working on your E2020 course! The Public Education Department has extended the deadline for seniors to complete graduation requirements to June 19, HOWEVER, that doesn’t mean you can stop working now and finish later. Seniors are expected to attend their scheduled classes unless technology prohibits them from doing so. They are expected to complete their assignments and projects. If a senior does not have internet at home, they are required to submit their assignments/projects on paper and return them on time to be graded by teachers. Seniors who choose not to stay engaged will put graduation at risk.

Special education students will continue to receive supports and modifications as outlined in IEPs. Special Education teachers and EAs will be attending the online classes and will have regular enrichment periods to work in smaller groups with students. Students who receive speech, occupational, or physical therapy will continue to receive service through an online provider. Our Special Education staff will be contacting families individually to assess your needs and get you going.

This is A LOT of information and I am sure you have many questions. I will be scheduling some online sessions to answer your questions or provide support next week. Look for an invite in your email and on facebook.

Please know that, while things will continue to rapidly change, our commitment to you has not wavered. We will continue to do everything we can to support you, our community, and – most importantly – our kids. We miss them and we can’t wait to start seeing them again on Monday, March 30. Please feel free to contact me with questions at director@mcsk12nm.org or 505-692-6090 extension 106. On behalf of the McCurdy Charter School staff, I want to thank you for your patience and trust.
Be well,
Sarah Tario, Director
March 25, 2020

p.style: color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "Trebuchet MS"; font-size: 13px;

hr.p: Hello Bobcat Families,

p.style: color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "Trebuchet MS"; font-size: 13px;

hr.p: We are waiting to hear from the Public Education Department and Governor about the plan for schools as we move towards the third week of closure. I will be sure to share information with you as soon as I have it. In the meantime, our staff has met together and developed a plan to begin providing online support and some instruction beginning on Monday. You should be hearing from teachers this week as we gather information about your technology resources. Once we know how many students have online capability, we will be able to decide how best to serve our students moving forward. Please be sure to respond to their emails and phone calls. Questions about grades, google classroom codes, or questions about specific classes should be directed to your child's teacher. They are regularly monitoring emails and working remotely.

p.style: color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "Trebuchet MS"; font-size: 13px;

hr.p: We will also be reaching out to you soon to complete a survey and provide feedback on our budget for the 2020/21 school year. Additionally, you can provide feedback at the regular Board Meeting scheduled for this Thursday at 6:00. This will be a virtual meeting; links and phone numbers to connect can be found on the attached agenda or the school website.

p.style: color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "Trebuchet MS"; font-size: 13px;

hr.p: We know this is a difficult and scary time for kids, families, and our MCS community. We are here to support you, please reach out to let us know how we can help.

p.style: color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "Trebuchet MS"; font-size: 13px;

hr.p: Be well,

p.style: color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "Trebuchet MS"; font-size: 13px;

hr.p: Sarah Tario, MCS Director

p.style: color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: sans-serif, Arial, Verdana, "Trebuchet MS"; font-size: 13px;

hr.p: p.s. Grab and go breakfast and lunch is still being offered for free daily. Thank you to our cafeteria staff for providing this essential service!
March 23, 2020

In accordance with directions from the NM Governor, we will be closing campus effective March 23, 2020. All staff will be working remotely unless there is an essential need to be on campus. We will be monitoring and responding to phone messages and emails. Grab and go meals will continue to be available.
March 20, 2020
Dear Bobcat Families,

As our spring break officially comes to a close today, I know that there is still a lot of uncertainty about what comes next. As of this afternoon, guidance from the Public Education Department has not changed and we are planning to resume school on April 6, 2020. I expect that more information and possible changes to that timeline will come in the next week, if they happen. As soon as information or changes are announced, I will be sure to share them with our staff and community.

Over the next two weeks of closure, our campus will have one school administrator, one person in the business office, and one person in the front office daily. These employees are there to provide essential supports only. The cafeteria will continue to provide free grab-and-go meals from 8:30 – 1:00 Monday through Friday. We are sincerely grateful for their efforts to keep our community’s kids fed throughout this time. The rest of the MCS staff will mainly be working from home. Please continue to email teachers and other staff as needed. The MCS staff will meet virtually next week to plan for the possibility of extended closure and to talk about what will happen when we return to campus. Many teachers are already providing resources to students and we have created a page on our website with links to resources. Just click on the CO-VID 19 tab on our front page: www.mcsk12nm.org

Like you might be, I have felt almost overwhelmed with all the information, resources, and uncertainty. The idea of “homeschool” for the next two weeks might be intimidating for some of us, while others will take to it naturally. I encourage you to keep it simple - kids can learn a lot of things through play, routine, and just helping out with cooking, cleaning, and other normal household jobs. Reading to and with your kids, having family dinner, and talking to each other will hugely benefit everyone “stuck” at home. In this time of uncertainty and fear, home can be a place of safety and peace.

Please do not hesitate to reach out if we can help you in some way. I am available through email (director@mcsk12nm.org) or you can leave a voicemail, which I check regularly: (505) 692-6090 ext. 106.
Sarah Tario, Director
